title: How to Front Float Safely

steps.headline: Ask a friend or family member to spot you while you float.
steps.description: You’ll probably be fine on your own, but having someone nearby is still a good idea. This will give you some added reassurance if you’re nervous, such as if you’re trying it for the first time or if you’ve struggled to do it other times you’ve tried. It will also help to ensure that you will have help if you need it. Try saying something like, “I want to try front floating. Can you please watch me from the edge of the pool to make sure I’m okay?”

steps.headline: Dip your toes into the water or stand in shallow water to get used to it.
steps.description: If you have a fear of water, you might want to start by getting used to being in the water first, such as by dipping in your toes and legs while sitting on the edge of the pool, or by playing in the water. This is also a good way to get used to the temperature of the water before you submerge yourself in it.

steps.headline: Stand waist-deep in the shallow end of a swimming pool.
steps.description: Ensure that the section of the pool you are in is shallow enough that the water is only about waist deep. This is a safe depth for practicing and it will make it easier for you to get up and out of the water when you are done floating. Avoid practicing floating in a pool that is so deep you cannot touch the bottom. Don’t practice floating in murky, moving, or open waters, such as in the ocean, a river, or a pond.

steps.headline: Grasp a pool noodle or other flotation device in each hand.
steps.description: You can use regular pool noodles to help keep your upper body afloat, slip inflatable or foam floaties over your arms, or grasp a kickboard in each hand. Whatever you have available that floats will work.Tip: If you do not have any flotation devices available, you could ask a friend, family member, or swim coach to help support you while you try to float, such as by placing their hands under your shoulders or holding your hands.

steps.headline: Inhale deeply a few times, then take a deep breath and hold it.
steps.description: Inhale normally a few times and then take in a deep breath and hold it right before you sink into the water. Hold your breath for about 10-20 seconds while you float. The air in your lungs will help to keep you afloat.

steps.headline: Bend forward until your face and upper body are in the water.
steps.description: Keep your chest, abdomen, and face pointed down towards the bottom of the pool as you transition into the front-float position. Don’t turn your head or body to the side. If you’re wearing goggles, look down at the bottom of the pool and enjoy the view! You may also want to wear a nose clip to keep water out of your nose while you float face down.

steps.headline: Position the flotation devices under your armpits or stomach.
steps.description: This will help to ensure that your upper body is supported and allow you to relax in the front float position. You can let your arms dangle down towards the bottom of the pool, which is known as the jellyfish float, or keep them straight out at your sides or up over your head. If you’re using pool noodles, position each one so it’s under your armpit. If you’re using a kickboard, slide it under your belly to help you stay afloat. If you’re using inflatable arm floaties, slide them onto your arms and put your arms out to your sides.

steps.headline: Lift your legs up so they are in line with your back or let them dangle.
steps.description: Extend your legs straight out behind you if you’re able. Use your leg muscles to bring them up to the surface of the water. If this is too difficult, it’s also okay to let your legs dangle down towards the bottom of the pool, like a jellyfish would. Just make sure to keep your back straight as you do this. You may also place a pool noodle under your legs or wear floating fins to help get your legs up.

steps.headline: Lift your face out of the water and stand back up when you’re ready.
steps.description: Relax in the floating position for as long as you’re able or want to. Make sure to bring your face up and out of the water when you need to take a breath. Return to a standing position when you’re ready. Repeat the exercise after breathing normally for 3-5 minutes.

steps.headline: Try the jellyfish float by letting your arms and legs dangle down.
steps.description: Start by standing waist-deep in the water, then take a deep breath and submerge yourself in the water. Allow your legs and arms to dangle down towards the bottom of the pool while you float. Relax and stay in this position for as long as you like.Tip: If you’re teaching a child to float, the jellyfish drill is a great option. You could also try asking the child to do something while they are under the water to distract them, such as blow bubbles out of their mouth or count the number of fingers you’re holding up if they’re wearing goggles.

steps.headline: Do the “I” drill to float with your body in a straight line.
steps.description: Stand waist deep in the water, take a deep breath, and then bend forward until your face is submerged. Stretch your arms out in a straight line above your head and extend your legs out in a straight line behind you as you float. Hold this position while you float.If your legs won’t stay up, you can support them with a flotation device, such as a pool noodle.

steps.headline: Alternate between extending your arms and legs into a “Y” shape.
steps.description: Stand in waist-deep water, take in a deep breath and bend down until your face is submerged in the water. Get into the “I” shape position, extend your arms outwards into a “Y” shape, then slowly bring them back to the “I” shape position. Next, keep your arms in the "I" shape position, extend your legs out into an inverted “Y” shape, and slowly bring them back into an “I” shape again.Continue to alternate and float this way for as long as you like. Moving your arms and legs in alternating fashion while you float will challenge you and help to improve your front-floating skills.

steps.headline: Move your arms and legs simultaneously from an “I” to an “X” shape.
steps.description: Take a deep breath and submerge your face in the water as you lean into the front-float position. Move your legs and arms outwards at the same time so your body looks like an “X” from above. Then, bring your arms and legs back into an “I” shape at the same time.Repeat this for as long as you like. This drill is similar to the “Y” drill, except you’ll be moving your arms and legs outwards and inwards at the same time instead of alternating them.

tyn: 2 pool noodles or other flotation devices
text: Floating with Assistance Ask a friend or family member to spot you while you float. You’ll probably be fine on your own, but having someone nearby is still a good idea. This will give you some added reassurance if you’re nervous, such as if you’re trying it for the first time or if you’ve struggled to do it other times you’ve tried. It will also help to ensure that you will have help if you need it. Try saying something like, “I want to try front floating. If you have a fear of water, you might want to start by getting used to being in the water first, such as by dipping in your toes and legs while sitting on the edge of the pool, or by playing in the water. This is also a good way to get used to the temperature of the water before you submerge yourself in it. Stand waist-deep in the shallow end of a swimming pool. Avoid practicing floating in a pool that is so deep you cannot touch the bottom. Don’t practice floating in murky, moving, or open waters, such as in the ocean, a river, or a pond. If you’re wearing goggles, look down at the bottom of the pool and enjoy the view! You may also want to wear a nose clip to keep water out of your nose while you float face down. Position the flotation devices under your armpits or stomach. This will help to ensure that your upper body is supported and allow you to relax in the front float position. You can let your arms dangle down towards the bottom of the pool, which is known as the jellyfish float, or keep them straight out at your sides or up over your head. If you’re using pool noodles, position each one so it’s under your armpit. If you’re using a kickboard, slide it under your belly to help you stay afloat. If you’re using inflatable arm floaties, slide them onto your arms and put your arms out to your sides. Lift your legs up so they are in line with your back or let them dangle. Extend your legs straight out behind you if you’re able. Use your leg muscles to bring them up to the surface of the water. If this is too difficult, it’s also okay to let your legs dangle down towards the bottom of the pool, like a jellyfish would. Just make sure to keep your back straight as you do this. You may also place a pool noodle under your legs or wear floating fins to help get your legs up. Lift your face out of the water and stand back up when you’re ready. Relax in the floating position for as long as you’re able or want to. Make sure to bring your face up and out of the water when you need to take a breath. Return to a standing position when you’re ready. Repeat the exercise after breathing normally for 3-5 minutes. Trying Different Front-Floating Techniques Try the jellyfish float by letting your arms and legs dangle down. Start by standing waist-deep in the water, then take a deep breath and submerge yourself in the water. Allow your legs and arms to dangle down towards the bottom of the pool while you float. Relax and stay in this position for as long as you like.Tip: If you’re teaching a child to float, the jellyfish drill is a great option. You could also try asking the child to do something while they are under the water to distract them, such as blow bubbles out of their mouth or count the number of fingers you’re holding up if they’re wearing goggles. Do the “I” drill to float with your body in a straight line. Stand waist deep in the water, take a deep breath, and then bend forward until your face is submerged. Stretch your arms out in a straight line above your head and extend your legs out in a straight line behind you as you float. Hold this position while you float.If your legs won’t stay up, you can support them with a flotation device, such as a pool noodle. Alternate between extending your arms and legs into a “Y” shape. Stand in waist-deep water, take in a deep breath and bend down until your face is submerged in the water. Get into the “I” shape position, extend your arms outwards into a “Y” shape, then slowly bring them back to the “I” shape position. Next, keep your arms in the "I" shape position, extend your legs out into an inverted “Y” shape, and slowly bring them back into an “I” shape again.Continue to alternate and float this way for as long as you like. Moving your arms and legs in alternating fashion while you float will challenge you and help to improve your front-floating skills. Move your arms and legs simultaneously from an “I” to an “X” shape. Take a deep breath and submerge your face in the water as you lean into the front-float position. Move your legs and arms outwards at the same time so your body looks like an “X” from above. Then, bring your arms and legs back into an “I” shape at the same time.Repeat this for as long as you like. This drill is similar to the “Y” drill, except you’ll be moving your arms and legs outwards and inwards at the same time instead of alternating them.

You’ll probably be fine on your own, but having someone nearby is still a good idea.
This will give you some added reassurance if you’re nervous, such as if you’re trying it for the first time or if you’ve struggled to do it other times you’ve tried.

If you have a fear of water, you might want to start by getting used to being in the water first, such as by dipping in your toes and legs while sitting on the edge of the pool, or by playing in the water.
This is also a good way to get used to the temperature of the water before you submerge yourself in it.

If you’re wearing goggles, look down at the bottom of the pool and enjoy the view!
You may also want to wear a nose clip to keep water out of your nose while you float face down.

This will help to ensure that your upper body is supported and allow you to relax in the front float position.
You can let your arms dangle down towards the bottom of the pool, which is known as the jellyfish float, or keep them straight out at your sides or up over your head.
If you’re using pool noodles, position each one so it’s under your armpit.
If you’re using a kickboard, slide it under your belly to help you stay afloat.
If you’re using inflatable arm floaties, slide them onto your arms and put your arms out to your sides.
Lift your legs up so they are in line with your back or let them dangle.
Extend your legs straight out behind you if you’re able.
Use your leg muscles to bring them up to the surface of the water.
If this is too difficult, it’s also okay to let your legs dangle down towards the bottom of the pool, like a jellyfish would.
Just make sure to keep your back straight as you do this.
You may also place a pool noodle under your legs or wear floating fins to help get your legs up.

Trying Different Front-Floating Techniques Try the jellyfish float by letting your arms and legs dangle down.
Start by standing waist-deep in the water, then take a deep breath and submerge yourself in the water.
Allow your legs and arms to dangle down towards the bottom of the pool while you float.
Relax and stay in this position for as long as you like.Tip: If you’re teaching a child to float, the jellyfish drill is a great option.

You could also try asking the child to do something while they are under the water to distract them, such as blow bubbles out of their mouth or count the number of fingers you’re holding up if they’re wearing goggles.
Do the “I” drill to float with your body in a straight line.

Hold this position while you float.If your legs won’t stay up, you can support them with a flotation device, such as a pool noodle.
Alternate between extending your arms and legs into a “Y” shape.
Stand in waist-deep water, take in a deep breath and bend down until your face is submerged in the water.
Get into the “I” shape position, extend your arms outwards into a “Y” shape, then slowly bring them back to the “I” shape position.

Next, keep your arms in the "I" shape position, extend your legs out into an inverted “Y” shape, and slowly bring them back into an “I” shape again.Continue to alternate and float this way for as long as you like.
Moving your arms and legs in alternating fashion while you float will challenge you and help to improve your front-floating skills.

Take a deep breath and submerge your face in the water as you lean into the front-float position.
Move your legs and arms outwards at the same time so your body looks like an “X” from above.
Then, bring your arms and legs back into an “I” shape at the same time.Repeat this for as long as you like.
This drill is similar to the “Y” drill, except you’ll be moving your arms and legs outwards and inwards at the same time instead of alternating them.
